note.p: William Yerger served as a justice on Mississippi’s Supreme Court and in the Mississippi legislature during the Civil War.

Born on November 22, 1816, in Lebanon, Tennessee, Yerger attended the University of Nashville, studied law, and became a practicing attorney at the age of 21. He moved to Jackson, Mississippi, in 1837 and established a successful law practice. He belonged to the Whig Party, an association some in Mississippi later said slowed his ascent within the state’s strong Democratic public and political setting. However, in 1850 he was elected to Mississippi’s High Bench of Errors and Appeals (later called the Supreme Court). He served on the Court for three years, before returning to legal practice.

During the Civil War, Yerger served in the Mississippi legislature, and was active in the immediate postwar effort to reconstruct the state government under President Andrew Johnson’s lenient policies for readmission to the Union. He established a very strong reputation as an attorney and jurist in Mississippi, so much so that the state’s Supreme Court adjourned for a day in his honor upon receiving word of his death on June 7, 1872, at the age of 55. Yerger had been married to Malvina Hogan Rucks and had five children. He is buried in Greenwood Cemetery at Jackson, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave; James D. Lynch, The Bench and Bar of Mississippi, 326-341)
William Yerger belonged to the following social groups:
William Barksdale was a U.S. congressman who later served as a Confederate general.

Born on August 21, 1821, in Smyrna, Tennessee, Barksdale graduated from the University of Nashville and moved to Mississippi to practice law. He eventually left his law practice to edit the Columbus Democrat, a pro-Democratic Party, pro-slavery newspaper in Columbus, Mississippi. During the Mexican-American War, from 1846 to 1848, Barksdale joined the Second Mississippi Regiment, serving as a quartermaster (supply officer).

After leaving Mexico, Barksdale returned to Mississippi and entered the political arena. He supported the Compromise of 1850, the controversial agreement among northern and southern politicians over the matter of slavery in the territories won from Mexico after the Mexican-American War. He won election to the U.S. House of Representatives in 1852, and served in Congress until the outbreak of the Civil War in 1861. Barksdale was an outspoken defender of slavery in Congress, being present in several high profile debates and incidents on Capitol Hill. This included Representative Preston Brooks’ assault upon Senator Charles Sumner in the U.S. Senate on May 22, 1856. Brooks, a pro-slavery Democrat from South Carolina, had taken offense to an anti-slavery speech by the senator from Massachusetts. He walked up behind Sumner and began beating him with his cane, nearly killing him. The “caning of Charles Sumner” marked another polarizing incident in the brewing political battle over slavery, and Barksdale was reportedly standing next to Brooks during the attack. Barksdale was part of another physical altercation between anti-slavery and pro-slavery representatives in Congress two years later. During the fight, a northern congressman tried to restrain Barksdale and inadvertently knocked his toupee off. When the Mississippian quickly and awkwardly replaced the hair piece on his head backwards, laughter broke out and ended the brawl.

After Mississippi seceded in January 1861, Barksdale resigned his seat in Congress and volunteered for state military service. He was commissioned a brigadier general and appointed adjutant general and then quartermaster general of the Mississippi Militia. Soon afterwards he transferred to the Confederate States Army as a colonel and commanded the Thirteenth Mississippi Infantry Regiment at the First Battle of Bull Run. Over the next two years he participated in several other battles in the Eastern Theater, including the Peninsula Campaign and the Seven Days Battles. After his brigade commander was mortally wounded at the Battle of Savage’s Station, he took over command and performed well, being promoted to brigadier general and leading to the brigade proudly being known as “Barksdale’s Mississippi Brigade.” Over the next few months Barksdale led his brigade at Antietam, Fredericksburg, and Chancellorsville.

Barksdale commanded his brigade at Gettysburg in July 1863. He led his troops during the sudden Confederate assault on the Union left flank on July 2, striking federal troops at the Peach Orchard and pressing them back. During the vicious fighting, Barksdale was shot in the knee, struck in the foot by a cannon ball, and then shot in the chest. Knocked off his horse by the final wound, Barksdale reportedly told a staff officer, “I am killed! Tell my wife and children that I died fighting at my post.” He died the following day, July 3, 1863, at a Union field hospital.

Barksdale was married to Narcissa Lucille Smith and had two children. He was also the older brother of Ethelbert Barksdale, who served in the Confederate Congress during the Civil War and the U.S. House of Representatives in the 1880s. Barksdale’s remains were transported from Gettysburg to Mississippi where he was buried at Greenwood Cemetery in Jackson.
(Wikipedia; American Battlefield Trust; FindaGrave)
William Barksdale belonged to the following social groups:
Orlando Davis was an attorney, politician, and judge in Mississippi during the nineteenth century.

Born on September 13, 1813, in Virginia, Davis moved to Ripley, Mississippi, as a young man. He studied law and became a successful attorney in Tippah County. By the 1840s he was active in public and political circles, and ran for state legislature as a Whig. He was a leading Union delegate to conventions in Tennessee and Mississippi held during the national political debate over the Compromise of 1850 and the future of slavery in federal territories gained after the Mexican-American War. Davis continued to be a Union and compromise politician through the 1850s, supporting the Constitutional Union candidate John Bell during the 1860 presidential election. However, after the election of Abraham Lincoln, Davis was a delegate to Mississippi secession convention and ultimately supported the state’s separation from the Union.

Davis remained in his home town of Ripley and practiced law during much of the Civil War. He provided moral and subsistence support for Confederate troops, being credited with delivering supplies to Mississippi troops in the field. After the war, he served as a circuit court judge. Davis died on August 4, 1898, at the age of 84. He was married to Martha McGee and had at least one child. Davis is buried in Hill Crest Cemetery in Holly Springs, Mississippi.

(FindaGrave; The Semi-Weekly Leader, Brookhaven, MS, August 10, 1898; Holly Springs Gazette, April 6, 1844; The Ripley Advertiser, Ripley, MS, March 2, 1844; The Semi-Weekly Mississippi Free Trader, Natchez, MS, June 20, 1843; Flag of the Union, Jackson, MS, September 12, 1851; The Weekly Mississippian, Jackson, MS, August 8, 1860; The Weekly Mississippi Pilot, Jackson, MS, August 20, 1870)
Orlando Davis belonged to the following social groups:

person.note:
Categories:
People -- African Americans

note.p: Alexander K. Davis was a representative in the Mississippi legislature and served as the state’s lieutenant governor from 1874 to 1876, during Reconstruction. He was the first African American lieutenant governor of Mississippi.

Little was recorded of Davis’ past. His date and place of birth are not known. During testimony before Congress in 1871 he explained that he moved to Noxubee County, Mississippi, from Tennessee in 1869, and said he had been admitted to the bar (a reference that he had been accepted as a practicing attorney in a city or county), but did not specify in which state. He won a seat in Mississippi’s House of Representatives shortly after coming to Mississippi and became a leading figure in the state’s Republican Party circles. In 1873, Radical Republicans backed by a majority of African American voters in Mississippi, won a series of state elections. Davis was one of three African Americans elected to statewide office that year, winning the lieutenant governor seat. (The other Black figures to win statewide election were James Hill as secretary of state and T. W. Cardozo as state superintendent of education.) The following year, white conservatives carried out a campaign of intimidation and violence to suppress Republican and African American voting and put Democrats into political power. The effort worked and by 1875, Democrats held a majority of state legislative seats. Emboldened by their political power, Democrats tried to rid Republicans from many state positions. They specifically targeted Davis and northern-born and Radical Republican Governor Adelbert Ames, accusing both men of improprieties in office. Davis was charged with illegal granting of pardons. Despite his effort to fight the trumped-up charges, Mississippi Democrats impeached Davis in March 1876. Knowing that the conviction would result in him being removed from office, Davis resigned. Governor Ames, also facing politically-driven impeachment proceedings that would require extensive time and financial resources to fight, resigned as well. Following his resignation, Davis abandoned politics. He moved to Canton, Mississippi and worked as a pastor. He died on November 21, 1884.
(Wikipedia; Dernoral Davis, "Alexander K. Davis," Mississippi Encyclopedia; Clyde Tucker, “Alexander K. Davis (?-1884),” Black Past)
Alexander Kelso Davis belonged to the following social groups:
James Spencer Bailey belonged to the following social groups:

Currently located in Grenada County, Grenada was founded in 1836 in what was then Yalobusha County. When Grenada County was created on May 9, 1870, Grenada became the county seat. (Wikipedia; Britannica; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

Currently located in Marshall County, Holly Springs was founded in 1836 in what was then Monroe County. When Marshall County was created on March 1, 1836, Holly Springs became its county seat. (Rowland, Mississippi, 874; Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)
Located in Mississippi, Montgomery County was created from Carrol and Choctaw counties and founded in 1871. (Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

gloss.p: Engaging in "illegal activities." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The crime of taking something that does not belong to you, but not in a way that involves force or the threat of force." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The crime of illegally taking something that belongs to someone else." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The processing of individuals who have committed criminal acts." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The act of using legal authority to catch and take someone to a place where the person may be accused of a crime." (CD)
"An amount of money set as a reward," typically to incentivize capturing a fugitive from justice. (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Having officially been found guilty of a crime in a law court." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The act of formally accusing someone of a serious crime." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The hearing of statements and showing of objects, etc. in a law court to judge if a person is guilty of a crime or to decide a case or a legal matter." (Cambridge Dictionary)

While the Mississippi Constitution grants each chamber some unique power, the House and Senate are equal partners in the legislative process as both chambers are required to enact legislation. Bills are originated in either house, and to become law, must receive a simple majority in both chambers. Once passed, it is sent to the Mississippi state governor for passage, veto, or pocket-veto, and the state legislature can overcome the veto with a two-thirds majority vote. (Wikipedia)

catDesc.term: Entertainment & Vices--Drug and Alcohol Consumption and Intoxication

gloss.p: "Having lost some control of your actions or behavior under the influence of alcohol or another drug." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who is in charge of a trial in a court and decides how a person who is guilty of a crime should be punished, or who makes decisions on legal matters." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A public officer who judges local and less important legal cases, and performs marriage ceremonies." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Individuals responsible for enforcing laws in designated areas." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"In the U.S., an official whose job is to be in charge of performing the orders of the law courts and making certain that the laws are obeyed within a particular county." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person with special training in the medical field." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A medical doctor, especially one who has general skill and is not a surgeon." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A place where trials and other legal cases happen, or the people present in such a place." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"In the U.S., a group of people who decide if a person who has been charged with a crime should be given a trial in a law court." (Cambridge Dictionary)

The term "fugitive from justice" is defined broadly and covers a multiplicity of experiences under U.S. law, but refers most often to "a person who is fleeing from custody, whether it be from jail, a government arrest, government or non-government questioning, vigilante violence, or outraged private individuals" (Wikipedia). Slightly different than the above definition, a fugitive from justice may also be defined as "a person formally charged with a crime or a convicted criminal whose punishment has not yet been determined or fully served who is currently beyond the custody or control" of the party, be it local, national, or international, interested in their arrest (Wikipedia). In the nineteenth-century United States, fugitive status varied widely based on race. Many white people considered "fugitives from justice" were most often the latter definition, being those charged with or convicted of crimes who then fled across other state lines to try and evade punishment or trial. However, throughout American history up to Emancipation, fugitive status was given to escaped enslaved African Americans under the Fugitive Slave Laws of 1793 and later 1850. These laws also required anyone in the nation to apprehend self-emancipated enslaved people and return them to their owners. The term "fugitives from justice" therefore became another legal mechanism by which enslavers sought to control the movements and freedoms of the enslaved, while contributing heavily to the increasing sectionalism that would lead to the American Civil War (Britannica). To learn more about enslaved people who emancipations themselves and were labeled fugitives, see the "Emancipation and self-emancipation" subject tag under Events.

div.p: [note] July 29, 1875 [/note]

The State of Mississippi
Montgomery County

To his Excellency
A. K Davis Lieut-Govenor and acting Govenor of the State of Mississippi.

Your petitioners Citizens of Montgomery County and State aforesaid would respectfully represent unto Your Excellency, that heretofore to-wit at the Aprile Term 1872 of the Circuit Court of said county one A. G. Ellis and—Gray were Indicted by the Grand Jury of said County for Grand Larceny.

Your petitioners, would further represent unto Your Excellency that said—Gray at or before the said finding by the Grand Jury aforesaid had left this state and your peti-tioners are not informed as to his whereabouts.

Your petitioners would further show, that said alledged crime was commited while in a state of intoxication, and as soon as said Ellis and Gray became conscious of their acts & doings while so intoxi-cated, they returned said alledged stolen Goods to the rightful
owner of the same, and made satisfactory reparation to said owner for their said offence, so far as he was individually conce-rned
Your petitioners would state, that the property alledged to have been stolen and returned as aforesaid consisted of Four Pares of Boots valued by the owner aforesaid at $900 per pare.

Your petitioners would further represent unto Your Excellancy that soon after the commition of said alledged offence said Ellis and—Gray were tryed for the same before one G. H. Dashnor an acting Justice of the Peace of said County and said justice deeming in his judgment that he had full Jurisdiction of the matter, then and there tryed and disposed of the same, as to him was right and proper in the premises and in accordance with the law's of said State.

Your petitioners would further state unto your Excellancy that said A. G. Ellis for whome releaf is preyed (with this exception) has always been & still is a good and law abiding citizen, and had he not been under the influence of Intoxicating liquors would (in the opinion of your petitioners) never have commited said offence
The premises considered Your petitioners would prey your Excellancy to Grant said A. G. Ellis such releaf as to Your Excellancy may seem meet & proper and your petitioners will ever pray &c

J. G. Harris
R. A. Ward
Humphy ^his X mark^ Ward
George ^his X mark^ Fredrick
?. R. Mecklin
J. W. Armstrong
D. L. Brown

Holly Springs, July 29, 1875—

I have no Knowledge whatever of the facts set forth in this petition, and can therefore make no recommendation on the subject. I was not the Judge who presided when the indictment referred to, was found by the Grand Jury. Mont-gomery County, at that time, belonged to Judge Niless district.

As this is an application for a pardon before conviction, it offers a convenient oppertunity for me to express my general disapproba-tion of such pardons. ^upon grounds of public policy.^ There may be extremely exceptional cases that will justify them, but they must be of very rare occurrence, and I do not undertake to say whether this is one or not.

I will also take the liberty of suggesting that when such pardons are granted, the interest of the State will be greatly promoted by making the pardon conditional, requiring the party pardoned to pay all costs, for which the State would in any event, be liable.—See White vs The State, 42 Missi R. 635.

O. Davis.
Judge 10th Cir. C. Dist

I was not Dist Atty for Mont-gomery County at the time re-referred to in the within petition—had no connection whatever with it—Know nothing of the facts of the case, and have no recommendation to make—only this that on general principles I am opposed to a too free exercise of the pardoning power

Jas T. Fant
Dist Atty

Holly Springs
Aug 7th '75

I do not recall any of the facts of this case as they were detailed before the Grand Jury. I heartily concur in the remarks of Judge Davis on the exercise of the Pardoning Power in advance of conviction & especially before arrest & while the criminal is yet a fugitive & a reward still offered by the same authority that pardons him.

W R Barksdale
Dist Atto
Aug 8, 75
